title-group.article-title: Optimization of limestone sawing using circular saws with reference to unit wear and energy

abstract.p: Natural stone processing operations use different methods and machines; however, the circular sawing machines are widely used in natural stone processing since they can be used flexibly. The wear on the diamond segments on the sawblade and energy consumption are the important parameters for these machines. Unit wear and unit energy should be minimized and the sawing rate should be maximized for optimum sawing condition. In this study sawing tests were performed on limestone samples using a fully automatic circular sawing machine. The tests were conducted at different peripheral speeds and advance rates. For each sawing test, the segment wear and consumed energy were measured. The statistical software, Design Expert 7.0 was used to analyze the test data. The new sawability charts for wear and energy were developed. The unique aspect of this study is to determine the optimum circular sawing performance with the special software and this technique also provides the prediction of unit wear and unit energy for selected sawing condition.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Natural stone processing plants are essential to produce goods according to market demand at the lowest possible cost thus; the processes should be carried out efficiently. In these plants there are various machines that require a large investment from the company. The circular sawing machine is the one of the machines that is used to produce slab/strips from stone blocks. The efficient and effective utilization of these machines increases the amount of production and decreases operating costs.

The most important issue in sawing operations is the selection of diamond segments suitable for the rock cut. To select a suitable segment, natural stone manufacturers need to determine the relationships between sawing conditions and the diamond segment parameters (type of matrix, particle size and amount of diamond). The sawing conditions of rocks (peripheral speed, advance rate, sawblade diameter, vibration, water consumption, etc.) have a significant effect on diamond segment wear. In order to determine the optimum sawing conditions, the variable parameters of the machine, peripheral speed and advance rate, should be determined according to the stone being cut with reference to unit wear and unit energy.1

The first studies on sawing systems began at the end of 1960s. Some studies were undertaken from 1960 to 1980 with the technology of those years, then since the 1980s more professional and detailed studies on rock sawing systems have been carried out. Ertinghausen2 examined the wear types occurring on circular saw. Wright and Cassapi3 found that, under constant sawing conditions, rock hardness was closely related with wear and energy consumption on different granitic hard rocks. Cassapi et al.4 performed experimental studies with a bridge sawing machine and correlated the sawing forces with the engineering properties of rocks. Pai5 stated that specific energy and power consumption were dependent upon several parameters at the grinding stage of the sawing process. Luo and Liao6 investigated the effects of diamond particle size and particle type (sharp, flat, broken particle, etc.) on sawing performance. Luo7,8 investigated the worn diamond segment surfaces and determined the wear types. Wright and Tagg9 emphasized that sawability and abrasivity were two important elements in selecting circular saw properties. Xu10 examined the friction characteristics in granite sawing with diamond segmented circular saws. In addition, he measured the sawing forces and determined the specific sawing energies. Konstanty11 indicated that the matrix wear on diamond segments affected sawblade characteristics. Brook12 developed a new index called as his name and tried to determine the vertical force during indentation of single diamond particle into rock. Li et al.13 explained that the wear on circular sawblades depended on the machine parameters as well as their combination with each other. Eyuboglu et al.14 developed a wear model by examining the statistical relationships between rock parameters and wear on segments. Wei et al.15 evaluated and classified the sawability of some granite. However, some of his conclusions were unsatisfactory. Xu et al.16 investigated sawing forces at different sawing conditions and calculated normal and tangential forces from horizontal and vertical forces. Ersoy and Atici17 examined the sawing forces and specific energy usage by changing the advance rate and sawing depth at constant peripheral speed on circular sawing machines. Kahraman et al.18 measured the amount of production in circular sawing operations on carbonate natural stones at various plants and developed statistical models based on physical and mechanical rock properties for determining the amount of production. Ersoy et al.19 performed sawing studies by correlating rock properties with changing the advance rate and sawing depth at constant peripheral speed using two different sawblades. Buyuksagis and Goktan20 performed experimental studies on sawing performance with real marble samples. Buyuksagis21 investigated the effects of sawing modes (up and down sawing) in granite sawing. Polini and Turchetta22 studied on monitoring the diamond circular saw wear by using force and vibration sensors in real marble sawing. Aslantas et al.23 investigated the effects of axial cutting forces on diamond sawblades and measured the axial deviation of sawblades. Buyuksagis24 determined the effects of diamond segment characteristics (diamond concentration, matrix compositions, matrix hardness, etc.) on sawing performance. Ucun et al.25 investigated the effects of diamond concentration on sawing forces, power consumption and specific energy at a constant sawing condition. Guney26 derived the models which include surface hardness and crystal size for the prediction of hourly slab production of carbonate rocks using large-diameter circular saws.

Apart from the above studies, regardless of the type of natural stones, some experimental, theoretical and numerical studies on sawing system were done. Jerro27 developed the mathematical model of chip geometry with kinematical analysis in circular sawing. Konstanty28 put forth theoretical models of natural stone sawing with diamond cutters. Tönshoff et al.29 studied on the sawing principles of diamond cutters and determined the wear principles. Brunetto et al.30 carried out experimental, theoretical and numerical studies on explaining the wear properties in abrasive materials. Ilio and Togna31 formed a theoretical wear model by using matrix and diamond particle properties in circular sawing. Yasitli et al.32 carried out the numerical modelling of reactional cutting forces in circular sawing and compared the modelling results with experimental results.

In earlier studies, in particular, the mechanisms of the circular saw and the sawing processes have been well documented. Many researchers have investigated the general application, sawing mechanism and sawability, design of circular saw, materials and manufacture, the effect of design on sawing, frictions in sawing and the effects of sawing parameters on rock. However, earlier classification studies did not extend beyond partial classifications based on a single specific property such as; blade wear, circular saw life, and the amount of production and the examination of the relationships between the basic parameters and the physical, mechanical, mineralogical and petrographical properties of the rock. There is no evidence in the literature of research into sawing optimization being carried out based on unit wear and unit energy values at different peripheral speed and advance rate. Therefore, this comprehensive study on circular sawing optimization in relation to the consumed energy and diamond segment wear for samples of limestone in Turkey is the first of its kind.

sec.title: Methodology
sec.p:
The fully automatic circular sawing machine designed for this study was developed in the Mining Engineering Department of Hacettepe University. The machine parameters effective on sawing (such as reactional sawing forces in X, Y and Z directions, vibration and consumed energy) can be measured and sawing conditions (including advance rate, peripheral speed and depth of saw) can be controlled accurately on this machine (Figure 1). The sawing head of the machine moves up and down on the vertical axis and the sawing table of the machine moves right and left on the horizontal axis mechanically. The sawing process is realized by the movements of these parts. It is possible to place circular saws with diameter of 400, 500 and 600 mm on the machine. Two inverters were used to control the peripheral speed and advance rate. Three dimensional reactional sawing forces were measured by means of platform type (single point) load cells. All the machine operations were controlled by computers and recorded in 250 ms intervals.1 Figure 1.
The model circular sawing machine used in the study.

In this study, seven different types of limestone were used with the commercial names of; Bilecik Rosalia Beige, Diyarbakır Hazar Pink, Karabük Rustic Green, Amasya Beige, Burdur Cream Creama, Sivrihisar Beige and Bursa Mustafakemalpaş a Beige. These samples were prepared in 20 × 30 × 50 cm mini blocks. For each sample sawing operations were performed under 24 sawing conditions at four different peripheral speeds (40–50–60–70 m/s) and six different advance rates (400–500–600–700–800–900 mm/min) with a 60 mm constant depth. The sawing operations were repeated 5 times for each sawing condition. The amount of water used in sawing was 20–22 l/min depending on the diameter of the sawblade. The circular sawblade used in this study had a diameter of 500 mm with 30 impregnated diamond segments of a C24 concentration. The dimensions of the segment were 40 mm long, 5.5 mm wide and 7 mm high. The diamond grain size used in segments is 40/50 Mesh (400/297 µm) and diamond quality of SDA 85 is used. The matrix is composed of cobalt and bronze. The grain sizes are 400 Mesh (37 µm) and 85/15 Mesh (158/1300 µm), respectively.

The wear on the diamond segment was measured with special designed measuring equipment (Figure 2) that consists of three linear gauges (one for vertical measurements and two for horizontal measurements) placed on a specially produced platform, digital signal converter, software for transferring the obtained data, and a computer to collect this data. The wear measure equipment was newly designed and used a novel technique for the accurate determination of segment wear. The wear was measured as the loss of height of diamond segment. The wear measurements were made after and before sawing on the same diamond segments. The difference of measurements gave the wear on diamond segment. At least 10 diamond segments were used for wear measurements. Average of the measurements was taken, thus the unit wear for each sawing condition was obtained. Figure 2.
The specially designed wear measurement equipment.

The consumed energy was measured with the energy analyzer on the machine. This analyzer assists in the measurement of the amount of instant energy and transfers it to computer. First, the energy consumption of main motor that gives the circular movement to the sawblade was measured without the contact between sawblade and stone block. Later, the energy consumption of main motor was measured during sawing process. The difference between two measurements was the net instant energy consumption. The method used in the study is shown in Figure 3. Figure 3.
The method used in the study.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: The statistical assessment part of the study aimed to analyze the design of the sawing experiments, analysis of obtained data and optimization of peripheral speed and advance rate in reference to unit wear and unit energy. In order to carry out the statistical analysis, Design Expert 7.0, was used. This software was developed for experimental optimization and it is widely used not only for the optimization of products and processes, but also for determining the most effective and suitable design of the experiments for different methods.

An experiment program was established according to the 2 factorial design model using Design Expert 7.0 and the sawing experiments on all the limestone samples were realized according to this program. The statistical assessments were accomplished under each of the sawing conditions. The averages of the wear and energy values obtained from the samples were used for analysis.

sec.p:

This information consisted of elements such as the mean and standard deviation that characterizes the distribution of the variables and also defines the methods and models used in the modeling studies. In addition to the defining statistics, the high correlations between the unit wear and unit energy with advance rates at different peripheral speeds were investigated and the results are given in Figures 4 and 5. Figure 4.
The relationship between advance rate and unit wear at different peripheral speeds.
Figure 5.
The relationship between advance rate and unit energy at different peripheral speeds.

The regression model involves dependent and independent variables. In such a model, the change in dependent variable is described with independent variables. The first stage in development of simple or multiple regression models is to determine the coefficients of the model and then the statistical test of validation of model with variance analysis. The results obtained are called ANOVA (Analysis of Variance) tables. The F-value calculated from the tables is the test value for the validation of the general model. The F-value and ANOVA results in regression analysis and in other models show the validation of the model that has been developed, in other words, these results show the representativeness of the system.

The unit wear and unit energy are highly related, according to Figures 4 and 5, with advance rate at different peripheral speeds. Three-dimensional reactional sawing forces (in X, Y and Z directions) acting on sawblade during sawing process, especially axial force (in Z direction) are effective on energy consumption and wear rate. For a given advance rate, energy consumption increases with peripheral speed, but the reactional sawing forces on sawblade decreases. Decreasing the reactional forces reduces the forces related to interaction and friction between stone and sawblade, and the sawing process realizes more easily; but the higher and inefficient energy is used due to the high peripheral speed of sawblade. Accordingly, for a given advance rate, the wear on diamond segments decreases with increasing the peripheral speed because of low reactional sawing forces acting on diamond segments.

sec.title: Statistical assessments of the sawing data
sec.p: Two basic parameters; unit wear and unit energy, were used in determining the sawing performance. Each parameter was evaluated separately in statistical analyses. In the other stage of the study, in order to determine the optimum sawing condition depending on unit wear and unit energy, the statistical model equations were developed by using advance rate and peripheral speeds and then the estimation at no data points was realized by these model equations. To demonstrate the reliability of the study different statistical model equations were derived using different models; the most significance statistical model was selected as most suitable for these parameters.

sec.title: Optimization
sec.p:
The main purpose of this study was to determine the optimum advance rate and peripheral speed for the minimum unit wear and unit energy in the circular sawing of different samples of limestone. For the optimization process, the Design Expert 7.0 statistical analyses program was used. In the final stage of the study, sawability charts were developed separately with respect to the unit wear and unit energy using the derived model equations. The sawability charts with respect to unit wear and unit energy under optimum sawing conditions can be seen in Figures 6 and 7, respectively. Figure 6.
The sawability charts including the optimum condition with respect to unit wear.
Figure 7.
The sawability charts including the optimum condition with respect to unit energy.

These sawability charts, given in Figures 6 and 7, can be used for predicting the diamond segment wear and the consumed energy according to selected sawing conditions (advance rate and peripheral speed). The sawblade life can be estimated with respect to sawing condition will be applied. It can be observed that how slow and fast saws (low and high of advance rates) affect the sawblade life. Consumed energy can be also estimated after sawing operation using these charts. The wear and energy values directly affect the production cost. The estimation of these two performance criteria helps to determination of production cost previously.

sec.title: Results and recommendations
sec.p:
In this study, the unit wear and unit energy, the optimum condition of peripheral speed and advance rate for the limestone samples in circular sawing and the sawability charts were developed using specific statistical software. It was found that the optimum sawing condition for the samples used in this study was 58.87 m/s peripheral speed and 749.98 mm/min advance rate. Accordingly:
Unit wear and unit energy values can be determined using the sawability charts after sawing operations at different peripheral speeds and advance rates.
Unit wear and unit energy values can be estimated in natural stone processing plants by creating such charts.
This assessment can provide an estimate of the sawing costs before commencing the sawing operation with circular saw. Furthermore, the unit wear values that have been estimated can help predict the life of the sawblade.
Manufacturers will be able to estimate the amount of sawing (m2) to meet their production targets as well as the costs involved.

The sawability charts present the estimated values of unit wear and unit energy for limestones. These values are the balance point (the optimum sawing condition) determined by considering the wear, energy, advance rate and peripheral speed. These sawability charts can be developed for different diamond segments. The optimum sawing condition can be determined separately by comparing these optimum sawing conditions. Then, suitable segment selection for the natural stone can be achieved. Consequently, these sawability charts can be also developed for different stone types (marbles and granites).
